node.title: Why hasnâ€™t the U.S. found more Omicron cases?
node.alt: Analyzing a Covid test sample in a lab in Houston. The country is now sequencing roughly 80,000 virus samples a week and 14 percent of all positive P.C.R. tests, but the process is time-consuming.
node.content: ["Last Friday, just a day after South African scientists first announced the discovery of the Omicron variant, Europe reported its first case: The new coronavirus variant was in Belgium. Before the weekend was out, Australia, Britain, Canada, Denmark, Germany, Israel, Italy and other countries had all found cases.", "But in the United States, scientists kept searching.", "\u201cIf we start seeing a variant popping up in multiple countries across the world, usually my intuition is that it\u2019s already here,\u201d said Taj Azarian, a genomic epidemiologist at the University of Central Florida.", "On Wednesday, American officials announced that scientists had found it \u2014 in a California patient who had recently returned from South Africa. By then, Canada had already identified six cases; Britain had found more than a dozen.", "The United States identified a second case, in Minnesota, on Thursday, and more are almost certainly lurking, scientists said. So why haven\u2019t we found them yet?", "Multiple factors may be at play, including travel patterns and stringent entrance requirements that may have delayed the variant\u2019s introduction to the United States. But blind spots and delays in the country\u2019s genomic surveillance system may have been factors, too, experts said. With many labs now conducting a targeted search for the variant, the pace of detection could quickly pick up."]
